subject: Re: [junit] questions about junit
msgSnippet: ... Track defects. Ron Jeffries www.XProgramming.com Accept your conditions, but not your fate.  -- Rod Walsh & Dan Carrison
messageBody:
On Friday, March 5, 2004, at 3:33:48 AM, Jason Rogers wrote:

>> On Friday, March 5, 2004, at 3:11:13 AM, Jason Rogers wrote:
>>
>> >> Looking foward to your suggestions?
>> > Unless there are time and money constraints (and possibly some other types of constraints) JUnit will be
>> > helpful to you if you are writing Java code.
>>
>> If the code has to work, I always wind up going faster with xUnit testing.
>>
>> If the code doesn't have to work, it's done now.

> Unfortunately, the developer doesn't always have the freedom to choose.
> What was implied in my message, though not obviously stated, was that
> the constraints come from higher-ups. If I had the choice, I would
> always test. But I have been in situations where that isn't possible
> (manager doesn't support testing and through micro-management was always
> watching whether you were or not).

Track defects.

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
Accept your conditions, but not your fate. -- Rod Walsh & Dan Carrison
